title: The Domesday Book: England's First Database
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: The Domesday Book: England's First Database.

hook.text: In 1086, William the Conqueror wanted to know exactly what he'd conquered. Every field, every cow.

buildup.text: Royal commissioners fanned out across England, recording every manor, mill, and meadow.

discovery.text: The Domesday Book cataloged 13,418 settlements â€” the most complete snapshot of medieval life.

twist.text: It was called 'Domesday' because its judgments were final â€” like the Last Judgment. No appeals.

climax.text: The book was used for tax disputes for centuries and still survives at the National Archives.

punchline.text: England's first database was a tax audit.

quiz.question: Why was the Domesday Book created?
options: To catalog all taxable assets in England
